awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A community 3D seismic investigation of fault property controls on slow-slip along the Hikurangi megathrust
awd_abstract_narration:
Subduction fault zones, where one of Earth's tectonic plates is forced beneath another plate, produce the most powerful and destructive earthquakes and tsunamis on the planet.  What controls this fault slip behavior is virtually unknown and yet it is critical for understanding and assessing global seismic hazards. While these great subduction zone earthquakes release seismic energy in a matter of seconds to minutes, recent discoveries reveal another style of fault movement called slow slip earthquakes (SSEs) that take days, weeks or months to occur. While not as damaging as major earthquakes, these slow slip earthquakes are nonetheless thought to be a critical process in how strain builds up and is subsequently released on subduction zone fault systems. Slow slip earthquakes may also act as indicators of where, and possibly when, large damaging earthquakes might occur.  The subduction zone along the east coast of the New Zealand North Island regularly (~ every 4 years) produces unusually shallow (4-5 km below the sea surface) slow slip earthquakes compared to the typical 20-50 km depths found in other areas such as the Cascadia and Alaska subduction zones on the west coast of the U.S.  This project will conduct a 3D seismic survey that is designed to image the shallow slow slip region of the New Zealand subduction zone, map the fault systems, determine what conditions are associated with slow slip behavior and how they differ from conditions associated with subduction zones that generate great earthquakes.  The project includes substantial international collaboration with New Zealand, Japanese and United Kingdom researchers on the seismic imaging as well as direct links with an international ocean drilling program designed to drill into the zone of slow slip. The project involves an early career scientist and several graduate students who will work on various aspects of the research for their thesis work. Additional students will be involved in the field data collection from all participating countries. Public outreach in the form of media coverage, news stories, public lectures and ship tours will be coordinated with New Zealand organizations and collaborators.

Slip on plate boundary faults associated with recorded earthquakes typically fails to account for all of the expected plate motion predicted by geodetic methods or global models. Exciting advances in the last decade have recognized and documented transient slow slip earthquakes as another mode to accommodate plate convergence at subduction margins. This project addresses the mechanics of subduction thrusts and the conditions that lead to the wide variety of slip behaviors by carrying out the first-ever 3D seismic dataset acquired over a subduction thrust dominated by aseismic creep.  The project will use the research vessel R/V Langseth to acquire an open-access 3D seismic reflection data set in a 15 x 60 km area offshore New Zealand's Hikurangi trench and forearc. These data will provide high-resolution images and seismic attributes of a transient-slip plate boundary megathrust identified by the research community as an important point of comparison to predominantly locked subduction thrusts such as Nankai, Tohoku, Cascadia, and Costa Rica. Seismic attributes linked to high fluid pressures are a promising indicator of conditions favorable for slow slip earthquakes and the Northern Hikurangi margin has well-documented slow slip earthquakes at 4-5 km depth - shallow enough for detailed seismic imaging and seismic attribute measurements. The 3D seismic images and attributes will allow for an accurate documentation of the structural, stratigraphic, and hydrogeologic conditions that lead to generation of slow slip earthquakes along a subduction megathrust. International collaborative experiments will record Langseth shots during 3D acquisition and develop the first ever high-resolution 3D velocity models across a subduction zone using 3D full-waveform inversion, which will overlap and extend beyond the 3D volume.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of Texas Institute for Geophysics

por.por_cntn:
The NZ3D 3D seismic imaging experiment was designed to examine structure, tectonics and the role of fluids in shallow slow slip earthquakes that occur within the subduction zone along the northern Hikurangi margin of New Zealand. Slow slip earthquakes are similar to regular earthquakes, but occur over periods of weeks rather than seconds. Why megathrust faults can exhibit these behaviors and when one is favored over the other is not known, yet knowing this is critical for understanding seismic hazards.

The project was also a collaborative project with the University of Hawaii at Manoa and was undertaken in two phases. The first phase (this project), acquired 3D seismic data and conducted an initial study of the most readily achievable objectives. The second phase of NZ3D will conduct advanced data processing and interpretation. During the initial phase (this project), the data acquisition was very successful, we have the necessary data for the next phase, and we were able to achieve our initial science goals.

As part of the intellectual goals of this project (Phase 1), the University of Texas group examined issues related to fluid and gas migration within this setting. We discovered some answers to long-standing questions about the stability of methane hydrates by looking at features known as double BSRs (bottom simulating reflections). Double BSRs occur where seismic reflections are generated at the current and relict stability boundaries between methane gas and frozen methane hydrate. The double BSRs occur because of a shift in pressure and temperature conditions. We discovered two separate mechanisms are responsible for creating the shifts. One is burial of the hydrate stability boundary by landslide deposits, which was confirmed by scientific drilling during Integrated Ocean Discovery Program Expeditions 372/375, and the second is a distinctly separate mechanism of tectonic uplift by thrust faulting. These mechanisms provide the most conclusive evidence to date for generating double BSRs, and help settle the debate regarding their origin in marine basins around the world. This also has implications for our primary goals of addressing fluid migration, thermal conditions, and faulting activity within the margin. It also has an added benefit of addressing methane (a powerful greenhouse gas) stability, and its release into the oceans and atmosphere.

The University of Hawaii group was also a collaborator during the first phase. They integrated regional shallow structure with recent drilling results from the IODP Expeditions 372/375. Recent tectonic activity in the slope basin of the upper plate directly above the megathrust is also implied from units imaged in the 3D data and drilled at Site U1519. Significant along strike variations of these units are consistent with continued thrusting within the underlying accretionary prism. Several sub-units are defined by internal stratal onlap and truncation, and help to understand the timing and magnitude of uplift and thrusting within the prism.

Strata on the Pacific plate east of the trench, sampled at IODP Site 1520 represent the inputs to the subduction zone. Our 3D data show that the input sequence is highly variable throughout the basin. The pelagic sequence contains sediment waves that are ~1km in width and ~300-400 m high and extend across the entire width of the volume. Overlying these deposits are trench strata that include the Ruatoria mass wasting deposits. These units are scrapped off from the subducting Hikurangi Plateau and form the materials that make up the upper plate, while the underlying sequences are subducted. These results will help to determine materials and conditions along the plate boundary megathrust that hosts earthquakes, and provide a basis for further work during the second phase of this project on subduction zone structure, tectonics, and fluid interactions that create a setting for slow slip earthquakes along the Hikurangi margin.

This project supported a Postdoctoral research scientist, Dr. Shuoshuo Han, to participate with the data acquisition at sea on the R/V Langseth, and provided her with an opportunity for training and career development in the field of marine geology and geophysics. She has also used the data from this project for her research and publications. NZ3D also included six PhD students from the UK and US, who also participated in the data acquisition at sea on the R/V Langseth.

In addition to early career development, this project addressed two societally relevant issues. The primary goal of this project was to understand the setting and physical property conditions that cause the subduction zone megathrust fault to slip in slow slip earthquakes. Understanding the behavior of the megathrust and the conditions that are conducive to these behaviors is critical for understanding seismic hazards for the Hikurangi margin as well as subduction zones globally. This project also provided new insight into the causes leading to changes in methane hydrate stability, which is highly relevant for understanding methane (a greenhouse gas) release from sediments into the oceans and atmosphere.

 


Last Modified: 02/11/2022
Modified by: Nathan L Bangs
